item.title: #en @ 1533976320052498432
item.description: If I see a resume with preprints, and the preprints have open data, and you have a GitHub page, I will hire you 10/10 over someone with an equivalent resume or even 'fancier' papers. I don't give a hot buttered fuck where you published. Show me HOW you published. https://t.co/B9W8KlIysG

item.title: #en @ 1533952268537667585
item.description:
We took essential services away from the most vulnerable in society in order to assuage the suddenly-hypochondriac upper-middle class in developed nations, undoing years of progress in the process.
I treated this as a generational failure, because it was. https://t.co/Wsgp9nHXuw

item.title: #en @ 1533892750025818112
item.description: Open data is key to advocating for change. Looking at traffic volume/speed data for a street I want to advocate for a road diet on, the data clearly shows there's a huge speeding problem (this street has a 40 MPH speed limit). item.description: The other advantage of this model is what's known as "linked open data". Wikidata items can be linked to external databases, e.g. Irish places are linked to their entries in the @logainm_ie database, Irish writers are linked to @ainm_ie, and so on.
